We can't use a dense asphalt with pre coated chippings rolled into the surface.
We can't use surface dressing.
We have a choice of a thin surfacing or we use high friction surfacing approaches to junctions so the Highways Agency as a customer a very committed to using this particular type of surface.
We don't have any choices of designer.
Unless we very insistent.
So it means that the requirements are in terms of technique, the road technique you're going to use, not in terms of properties.
We operate to a requirement for the Highways Agency.
Basically we have to use.
We have to use a thin surfacing in any designs or a high friction surfacing in proximity to high risk areas.

If there were some particular circumstances where we wanted to use an alternative material that has to be approved as a departure from the standard and then the research team, the pavement team within the Highways Agency.
Would review that on an individual basis, so we were totally committed to a negative textured surface in environment.
Similar within local authorities now, partly because the Highways Agency have that policy, but also it's very difficult to actually get old style materials.
Laid by contractors.
We don't get an opportunity because there's nobody there to do it anymore.

Personally, I would like to hear the nice noises.

Slovenia.

Especially.
With the motorways.

Motorways which has been built.

Yeah, thank you very much.

If we're doing designs for them, we have to use a thin surfacing similar to an SMAP but Pty materials, which are certified and they're all have some built-in noise attenuation.
We can't use a dense asphalt with pre coated chippings rolled into the surface.
We can't use surface dressing.
